post_title:
ST Engineering Land System.
Doesn't recommend.
text: Pros: 1. Very slow and relaxing pace 2. Some friendly people. Cons: 1. Very far behind outside world 2. Most skills and experience gained are irrelevant and outdated 3. Pay increment is pathetic 4. Simple change or improvement to workflow or culture takes forever or never. Mostly all talks and no action. 5. There are quite a number of engineers who are incompetence yet very very very arrogant. 6. Many mid management have zero contribution and add no value. Doesn't give direction and doesn't take liability, all these are pushed to the lower level staff. 7. Most fresh graduates who joined left after 2 years¬†
Pros: Stable job can work until retire. Cons: Low pay Low increament and Long overtime Too much audit internal QIC , PIC and Kaizen project

Pros: If you don't mind the conditions, you can get along with quite a lot of mediocrity without fear of reprisals Government-industrial complex stability, just don't upset the bigwigs and you'll be fine. Claims to be family oriented. Normally you won't be touched for holidays.. Cons: Low recognition and benefits, lower compensation. Inverted pyramid hierarchy. Dated thinking. Get used to doing pointless things just for your superiors to "look good". Weak growth opportunity. Self-fulfilling fetish for scholars. Workforce becoming transitory. Your colleagues are probably here because they lack experience, got retrenched or are some contracted-service. No loyalty or camaraderie. A lot of layers of middle management. Your bosses will expect you to give up your family time if urgent issues jeopardise their family time. A lot of armchair general and shadow ruler politics

Pros: Get paid to learn on the job, when you are actually working.. Cons: No urgency in program, most incoming trainees were told it would be an 18 month program and are still training at 2 years. Program leadership is unaware of the situation. No guarantee on when they will get you to the license testing.
Pros: None nothing to comment on this company. Please stay away.. Cons: Need to covet for 10 people and they don't hire

Pros: Colleagues that are also friends. Big team. Nice bosses as well. Seldom OT. Audit work program is really detailed. Good place to build a solid foundation on processes and controls. Wide variety of opportunities and audits.. Cons: Compensation. Not much flexibility on working hours.
They are really good medical insurance, good PTO

post_title: Toxic HR environment + Poor salary for current HR and other employees
text: Pros: no pros to share at all. Cons: - High turnover rate every week for most positions - Toxic HR environment and culture - Company give excuses for not adjusting poly to uni grads salaries - pathetic 1% Annual Increment - No progression / opportunities for growth at all - Bias appraisals from most bosses - no 360 appraisal unlike most and established companies - Work performance is not recognized - Team leads have no idea how to do their work and just push around to subordinates - No work life balance, too much workload and no one offer to help
Pros: There is no pros to mention. Cons: Most of the days are bad. Toxic management.
Pros: high salary, cozy environment, some decent people. Cons: coworkers with attitude issue, little to no direction in work
Pros: None. Experience to move on to better companies.. Cons: Horrible work environment. Horrible upper management. They can't even get HR managers to stay.

post_title: Large, mundane, not a place to stay long in
text: Pros: Stable, rarely fires people, provides training, does not usually make you work weekends or late into the night.. Cons: Boring, Pay is average, Hires even people that aren't qualified, Bosses don't have much power over your pay.
Very poor benefits in the company.
Overall very good and decent package
Good benefit , good care to employees
A lot of benefits. Thumbs up!
Pros: Stable. Get to leave on time on most days.. Cons: Erratic senior management. Prefer to hire externally than promote internally. High attrition rate. No replacement.

Pros: You get lousy pay for more work. Cons: Getting exploited, working for long hours. Boss complaining did not OT enough even though it's after 10pm and didn't have any dinner before this. 50 dollars increment per year. Micromanagement at its best.

Pros: Access to wide spectrum of learning opportunities and tech vendor/supplier's technology stack. For some strange reason, many tech vendors/suppliers cannot wait to share everything they have to ST Engineering. Cons: Career Opportunities - If you are a tech / software professional, there is no real professional growth and promotions are based on "beauty parade" and not merit. Bosses do not really understand tech/software deeply enough. Compensations & Benefits - Pay is poor for tech / software professionals, as it is far below industry rates. Pay is only good for "G Graders" (aka super scale senior management). Culture & Values - Fractured company as it is a collection of legal entities of SMEs. Culture (for Singapore entities) is not even across, but each of them generally operate like an local SME. Senior Management - Operate in their Ivory Tower, with no sense of the ground realities. Very numbers driven and they look good because of the overseas entities/assets that contribute to the topline. Work/Life Balance - Not even across the company. Free loaders will have very good work/life balance, while the productive employees work like hell.

Pros: 1. Good colleagues but it also depends the department you are working in. 2. These go both ways, if you are lucky, you will get a Reporting Officer (RO) who doesn't care about you, Hence, no micromanagement.. Cons: 1. Senior management have the mentality of "My ideas always worked before" and "I know what the customers truly wants" attitudes, does not listen to any of the actual employees that are working on the ground. 2. Salary is not competitive versus the market. 3. As a senior staff, you are expected to hold appointments in 3-4 projects at one time. The management will tasked the existing staff to take over any "leftovers" from the ones who left without the intention of hiring more manpower to reduce workload. 4. The management expects you to be overworked as it is common in the company and does not believe in giving you a better "salary package". 5. The management also does not believe in providing opportunities for the junior staff unless they are scholars. So if you are not "first class honours", progression will be real slow for you even if you met your KPIs. That being said, don't expect a super fast progression if you are first class. 6. Not really a major con but bosses like to come in 5-10 mins before your work day ends for meetings, so those rushing to fetch their kids, do note. 7. Micromanagement (only if you are that lucky enough to get an RO who is super into every single moves you made) 8. Decisions and changes from management takes about average 5-6 months to process. 9. On the ground engineers, I'm sorry but it is a fact that you won't be valued as much as those working at main office. (If you are not seen by the bosses, you are not contributing as much) 10. The company does conduct employee surveys. However, they will only take in the good and ignore the legit concerns from employees.
Pros: Good overseas opportunities, good pay. Cons: Bad management, bad culture, no two way feedback culture which leads to the worst leaders leading forever.
Pros: There are no Pros to think of. Cons: Rigid environment and poor management

Pros: work from home canteen food is cheap. Cons: VUCA environment , those who dont feel comfortable working in such environment should consider looking elsewhere the manager is clueless and not focus, no direction and guidance given to your work scope, you are expected to pick up and run the current work scope does not match the JD discussed during the interview extremely disappointed with the working experience in STE the expectation of this organization is already very low prior to joining but even that could not hide my disappointment

post_title: Might as well be a SBS Bus driver
text: Pros: Basic health care no questions asked. Can get a job even if you don't know anything. Paid training and can leave. Probably will never get fired. Good place for retirement.. Cons: Paid lesser than a SBS bus driver. If stay more than full 3yrs, stuck in the company forever. Unable to pass any companies interview. Brain drain. Compulsory overtime with no benefit. Unreasonable working hours. Unfair grading system with a fixed quota for each grade. Office politics on top of Division politics. Slowest progression in Singapore. Once you get the worst grade, you are guaranteed the same grade until you leave the company. Increment can be as low as 0% each year if employees stay silent. Turnover rate is quckier than an aircraft maintenance cycle.

Pros: The only good things about here is the colleagues. Cons: Came in as an E4 as assistant engineer. 1 person work on majority of the project, didnt get promoted. Lousy approving officer (AO) dont want to push me up for promotion even more than qualified to be a full engineer (E5). Pathethic increment and heard from someone my increment is consider pretty high in terms of (%) when I am clearly 30% underpaid compared to fresh grad. Fresh grad from private U come in already 4.8k. Need take how long to catch up with them?

post_title: Review on working in ST Engineering
text: Pros: ST Engineering has great work-life balance culture. The work culture is generally less stressful compared to other industries. The colleages and superior are helpful and encouraging. It would recommend to associate who desire stable employment.. Cons: There are too many level of management decisions that incurred conflict of interest for the lower section. Therefore, it is difficult to fulfill all decisions.

post_title: A technology company which is lagging behind others...
text: Pros: A good place for retirement. Cons: Feedback is reference to ST Engineering Electronics (now known as Digital Systems) <> Recent reorganisation made things worse with the additional middle layer, "mostly not inspiring". Apart from higher overhead expenses, the additional layer resulted in unnecessary reports, multiple deadlines and lower productivity. For example, an actual deadline in June will result in having 1 or 2 intermediate deadlines in May. Moreover, there are endless requests for multiple reports for the same information. The time would be better used on analysis, strategising and productivity improvement instead of churning reports. <> If not for Covid-19, digital transformation is unlikely to take place in this "Technology" company. Nevertheless, there is still great resistance to invest in things like docusign, adobe sign and other similar tools to reduce the amount of paperwork + transport time/logistic costs for multiple levels of approvals. Moreover, there are still managers/supervisors who ask local participants to gather in a room to carry out conference calls with overseas participants. Why do that during covid-19 pandemic (when WFH should be default) instead of allowing every participant to join conference calls directly from home? It would have been safer + more productive (saving staff transportation time and cost). <> There is a lack of learning culture in the organisation. Training opportunities are often limited to engineers, neglecting the need to train all employees to equip them with the right skills (& tools) to improve productivity. Hence, some Corporate functions are run by staff who lack basic skills such as MS Powerpoint, Excel, or Word. Examples - Some of the staff in IT are not even able to provide basic troubleshooting to assist staff. - There are managers/supervisors who are totally handicap when their staff are on vacation (or sick leave). They are not even sure how to make simple amendments to presentation slides or calendar invites. <> After years of 'Productization' talk, nothing much has changed. - Core Business still remains as: System Integration, White Labelling and Maintenance & Support. Many staff who have drive & passion to develop 'made in SIngapore' products eventually gave up and left the company Generally, there is a low sense of urgency and resistance to try new things or grow the business out of Singapore Government and Defence. Every new idea or initiative is often seen as 'more work' + 'higher risk of failure'. People tend to avoid being involved in new ideas/initiatives and carry on with their 'business as usual'. This 'lack of drive' mindset is terrible and results in low productivity and efficiency. Examples - An opportunity where overseas customer demand for 'shorter than usual timeline': Instead of trying to work towards customer's request, the team chose not to pursue the opportunity to build a track record. - Secretaries (most, not all) will ask most junior meeting participants to manage calendar invites, venue, setting up meeting rooms and arrange overseas travel. While in other companies, Secretaries not only take care of all administrative and logistic matters (calendar invites, setting up meeting venues, arranging overseas travel, etc.) but also join meetings to take minutes wherever possible. Interestingly, the canteen is always buzzling and it is strange how these people have so much time to chit-chat. Confidential discussions (among 8 or less colleagues) often ended up as an open secret. Many staff lack the maturity to keep confidential information to themselves and instead use it to boast that they know a lot. <> The frequent influx of military people into the company may not be wise. The company is not recruiting the best people from the market with the right skills for the job. It will not change the perception that the company is just a 2nd career for ex-military personnel. Moreover, it will make it difficult to change the deep-seeded culture in the company. The "Force" is strong with this company. May the "Force" be with them.

post_title: Low salary, slow progression, bad hr, bad TOP management, ancient dinosaurs
text: Pros: Very relax can go home at 5.30pm. Cons: Too relax. TOP management especially HR is bad. Hr policy and management is very backwards and military style since chief hr officer is ex military and has zero commercial experience. Salary is below market rate but hr still says it‚Äôs above market rate. There are people who are unable to promote even as an executive after 6 years. My department of about 25 people has 12 executives quitting in a 3 years period, yet hr does not bother to look into how to improve the situation. Colleague of mine went for exit interview and told hr that due to Low salary he is quitting. Hr actually reply ‚Äúit took you 2 years to realise the salary is bad?‚Äù Too many ancient dinosaurs in upper management resulting in old outdated management style.

post_title: Just another soulless job to get stuff done
